pageData.text: Microscopes allow scientists to observe cells and other details that are not visible to the naked eye. In this activity, you will learn about the parts of a microscope, slide movement, how to calculate total magnification of the microscope, basic care and handling of a microscope, and the importance of resolution and <button class='glossary-text'>depth of field</button>. The materials in this set have been selected to introduce the use of a microscope.

pageData.text: Wilson Bentley is credited with inventing the technique of photomicrography. Photomicrography is the art and science of taking images of objects under a microscope. Bently received his first microscope in 1880 when he was 15 years old. He looked at everything under the microscope, rocks, raindrops, feathers, flowers, but what fascinated him the most were snowflakes.

After two years of trial and error, on January 15, 1885, Bently became the first person ever to photograph a single snow crystal. He did this by removing the eyepiece from his microscope and connecting it to an accordion-like bellows camera; then, he placed a black card over the lens of the instrument so he could trace the enlarged image of the snowflake. He set up his equipment outside or in an unheated room to view and draw the snowflake before it melted. Over the course of his life, “Snowflake Bently” recorded images of over 5,000 snowflakes and verified the saying “no two snowflakes are alike.”

pageData.desc: A nowflake micrograph by Wilson Bentley.

pageData.text: Scientists use microscopes to observe objects that are too small to be seen (or too small to be seen in detail) with the unaided eye. Microscopes have played a pivotal role in our understanding of plant and animal cells, crystals, and microorganisms. Two common types of microscopes are <button class='glossary-text'>stereomicroscopes</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>compound light microscopes</button>. Both types manipulate light to create an enlarged image of an object.

Stereomicroscopes typically are used to view relatively large objects, such as fruit flies. They usually have a large <button class='glossary-text'>working distance</button>—the space between the lens and the specimen—which makes them ideal for use in dissections. For this reason, stereomicroscopes are often referred to as dissecting microscopes.

Compound microscopes are used to view even smaller objects. Objects viewed under a compound microscope are typically mounted on a microscope <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button>, a small, rectangular piece of glass, which is covered with a thin, protective piece of glass called a <button class='glossary-text'>coverslip</button>. A compound microscope has a much smaller working distance than a stereomicroscope.

Specimens intended for prolonged or repeated viewing with a compound light microscope are usually thin, and may also be chemically cleared. This allows light to pass through the specimen with a minimum amount of light scattering.

The scattering of light rays results in a loss of <button class='glossary-text'>resolution</button> (the ability to distinguish between two adjacent objects). The lower the resolution of an image, the blurrier it appears.

Specimens are often stained with one or more dyes during the preparation of a microscope slide. Most specimens, especially after they have been preserved and processed into thin sections, have little, if any, color. This results in very little contrast when the specimen is viewed. Dyes add contrast for greater ease of viewing.

Compound microscopes may also be used to view living specimens. Such a specimen is usually prepared as a <button class='glossary-text'>wet mount</button>, in which the specimen is placed under a coverslip with a small amount of liquid. Sometimes living specimens may be stained in order to enhance their contrast, but when they are not, the user must rely on careful lighting adjustments for optimal viewing.

When a suitably-prepared specimen is viewed with a properly-adjusted microscope, the resulting image will not only be magnified, it will also have high resolution and good contrast. Thus, the microscope will reveal fine details that could not be detected by the unaided eye.

Operating a MicroscopeTo observe objects under a microscope, you must first become familiar with the parts of a microscope (Figure 1 and Table 1). The shape and location of the major parts of a microscope can vary, so if you have trouble locating a component on your microscope, consult the instructions that came with your instrument. The Mini-Duo Scope User Manual that comes packaged with your microscope features a labeled picture in the Components section.

pageData.text: Every microscope possesses at least one <button class='glossary-text'>eyepiece</button>, or ocular lens. Those with only a single eyepiece are known as <button class='glossary-text'>monocular</button> microscopes. Many compound microscopes are <button class='glossary-text'>binocular</button> microscopes and have two eyepieces, which you look through with both eyes as you would with a pair of binoculars. The long cylinder extending from the eyepiece is called the <button class='glossary-text'>body tube</button>, or monocular tube. If there are two eyepieces and tubes, these are called binocular tubes. At the opposite end of the tube(s) are a series of magnifying <button class='glossary-text'>objectives</button>. Each objective magnifies objects to a different power. The lowest power is usually 4x, and is referred to as the <button class='glossary-text'>scanning objective</button>. The highest power is usually either 40x or 100x. For the purpose of this investigation, we will consider the 40x lens as the high power lens; this is often called the <button class='glossary-text'>high power (or “high-dry”) objective</button>.

There is usually a single objective between the scanning and high power objectives, most commonly with a magnification of 10x. It is known as the low power objective. The objective used to view an object can be changed by rotating the revolving nosepiece located near the bottom of the tube above the stage. Most modern microscopes are parfocal which means that if the image is focused, it should remain in focus when you change the objective with minimal fine-tuning using the fine adjustment knob.

pageData.subTitle: Depth of Field
pageData.text: It is important to remember that the objects observed under a microscope are three-dimensional. An object may appear flat, especially after being pressed under a coverslip. However, when magnified, the depth of the material on the <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button> becomes more apparent. When you view an object and only part of it is in focus, you are observing the limits of the microscope’s <button class='glossary-text'>depth of field</button>, which refers to the thickness (or depth) of an area under the microscope that can be viewed in focus. Depth of field is shallower on high power than on low power. For example, when you view an object under high power, less of it is in focus at one time than when the same object is viewed under low power. <button class='glossary-text'>Stereomicroscopes</button> offer a greater depth of field than compound microscopes because they are used at lower magnifications. In this investigation, you will have the opportunity to use your microscope as both a compound microscope and as a stereomicroscope.

pageData.text: Calculating MagnificationAn object is magnified by both the and the lens of the microscope. To determine the total magnification, multiply the magnification power of the eyepiece (which is typically printed near the lens) by the magnification power of the objective lens being used to view the object.
Total Magnification = (eyepiece lens power) ✕ (objective lens power)
For example, if human cheek cells are being viewed using the 40x objective lens with a microscope that has a 10x ocular lens, the total magnification of the cheek cells is 40x 10 = 400x.

Greater magnification does not always produce better viewing. A clear, sharp 200x image is more useful than a blurry 600x image. As magni-fication increases, the amount of light entering the lens decreases. Therefore, objects viewed at higher power will appear darker and may not be as clear. By adjusting the <button class='glossary-text'> diaphragm</button>, you can increase or decrease the amount of light directed onto the <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button>.

Basic Care and Handling of a Microscope and Microscope SlidesMicroscopes are delicate pieces of equipment. Follow the guidelines below to keep your microscope in the best possible condition.
  • Never touch the lenses of the microscope with your fingers.
  • Use only lens paper or cotton swabs to clean the lenses since fibers in paper towels or toilet paper can scratch the glass.
  • When storing a microscope, rotate the so that it is on the lowest power objective.
  • Adjust the stage so that it is as close to the objective as possible.
  • Keep the microscope covered when not in use to keep dust away.
  • Transport a microscope by using one hand to hold the scope by the arm and the other hand to support the base.
  • Store prepared microscope slides out of direct light to prevent stained specimens from fading.

If you have grown and observed bread mold or brine shrimp during your assigned activities, you may kill either with bleach, which is an excellent disinfectant. Be sure to wear PPE (gloves, apron, and safety goggles) whenever working with bleach and ensure that you are in a space with adequate ventilation.

pageData.text: For mold: Prepare a 10% bleach solution by mixing 1 part bleach with 9 parts tap water in a plastic or glass container with a lid that will not be used for food storage.

Soak the bread in the disinfectant bleach solution for 24 hours in a location that is off-limits to children and pets. Use enough bleach solution to completely cover and soak the bread. Carefully drain off the excess bleach solution in a sink, and dispose of the bread with other household waste.For brine shrimp: Brine shrimp should not be released to the environment because they are non-native organisms in many ecosystems. They may be transferred to a glass or plastic container with a lid that will not be used for food storage, along with an approximately equal amount of concentrated bleach. Let the shrimp soak in the bleach for 24 hours before disposing of them and the bleach down the drain, followed by a generous amount of tap water. A second disposal option is to freeze the shrimp overnight, and then pour them down the drain.
